description.narrative:
Föreslaget beslut innebär att International Media Support ges stöd att fortsätta arbetet för att stärka professionaliseringen av media i Irak under ytterligare två år - 2014-2015.
Programmet är fortsatt uppbyggt kring fyra komponenter - 1. Juridiskt skydd och säkerhet 2. Medias roll för att främja god samhällsstyrning och samverkan med civilsamhället 3. Kommersiell hållbarhet för oberoende tidningar/tidskrifter 4. Samordning nationellt och bland internationell aktörer.
Förlängningsfasen planeras innebära ett ökat fokus på de två förstnämnda komponenterna, motiverat av den försvårade politiska situationen i Irak, samt den förvärrade säkerhetssituationen, som inte minst mediaaktörer drabbas av.
Genom kortare eller längre partnerskap mellan IMS och enskilda eller nätverk av aktörer, genomförs aktiviteter och delprojekt som bidrar till uppfyllandet av insatsens fyra delmål (ett per programkomponent). Aktiviteterna innebär expertstöd, utbildning, nätverksbygge, påverkansarbete och samordning.
IMS har rapporterat goda resultat från pågående fas (2011-2013) bland annat vad gäller förbättrat juridiskt stöd och skydd för utsatta journalister, ökad kommersiell hållbarhet för mediaaktörer och därmed minskat politiskt beroende, mekanismer för skydd och stöd för utsatta journalister, stärkta nätverk för undersökande journalistik och och sociala media.

It is suggested that extended support to International Media Support is approved for continued work to strengthen professionalization of media in Iraq for two more years 2014-2015.
The program has four main components - 1. Legal protection and safety 2. Media, civil society, and good governance 3. Business development and network strengthening 4. Strategic development and harmonisation
The extension period will contain an increased focus on the two first components. The reason for this is the deteriorating political situation in Iraq, and the diffictult security situation that actors in the media sector are highly exposed to.
Through short- or longer term partnerships between IMS and single or networks of actors, activities and sub-projects are carried out which in turn contribute to the fulfilment of four outcome objectives (one objective per program component). The activities contain technical/expert support, training, networking, advocacy and coordination.
IMS has reported good results from the ongoing program phase (2011-2013), amongst others regarding enhanced legal support and protection for journalists, strengthened commercial sustainability for media outlets and thereby less dependence on political interests, mechanisms for protection for vulnerable journalists, strengthened networks for investigative journalism and for social media.

sector.narrative: Media and free flow of information

description.narrative:
General question: Results related to the intended outcome 2015Question: Summarise results related to the intended outcome (this information will be sent to Open Aid)Answer: The program "Strengthening Independent Media in Iraq and Kurdistan in Times of Insecurity" was implemented by International Media Support (IMS) during 2011-2015, with a total contribution from Sida of 27,2 MSEK (out of a total budget of 36,8 MDKK).
Due to the difficult security situation in large parts of Iraq due to the conflict with IS and the large number of IDPs this led to, many activities had to be cancelled or adjusted, especially during 2014. For example, several international consultants (trainers) cancelled due to security issues. Some partners were not able to maintain their political independence and cooperations were therefore phased out, while others went bankrupt.
Despite this, the program has managed to stay highly relevant wih a high local demand and the work of IMS has had a high added value for their partners in Iraq. Significant results have been achieved, especially within the components Legal Protection & Safety (which became even more relevant that at the outset) and Media, Civil Society and Good Governance.
Among the key outcomes of the programme has been the signing of a MoU between the security forces (who before the arrival of IS were the main threat to journalists' safety), lawyers and journalists which has changed the situation on the ground for journalists when covering e.g. demonstrations by making all parties more aware of the rights of journalists, and it has helped to ease tensions between journalists and security forces. Journalists have also received legal support from a network of voluntary lawyers, both through hotlines and in court cases, to decrease impunity for violations and journalists. The training in investigative journalism has furthermore led to Iraqi journalists winning several regional prices for their stories. Outreach was increased through support and trainings for bloggers. Lastly the establishment of a women’s magazine has had a short-term impact of creating a space and opportunity for female journalists, while having a long-term potential of helping to empower women and changing their social status in Iraq.
Though the war against IS, along with the financial crisis which started in 2014, made commercial sustainability for independent media unattainable, support from IMS contributed to keeping some of the few independent media voices alive.
The program has worked to ensure a diversity of partners and have included Arab, Kurdish, Yazidi, Christian, and Turkmen media actors. It was built on supporting local led initiatives, and this has helped ensuring local ownership which has increased the potential long-term sustainability of the program. The sustainability has furthermore been supported by the establishment of networks and contacts between relevant actors in the media sector.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
